source.title: Beyond Good and Evil
source.description: In Beyond Good and Evil, Nietzsche accuses past philosophers of lacking critical sense and blindly accepting dogmatic premises in their consideration of morality. Specifically, he accuses them of founding grand metaphysical systems upon the faith that the good man is the opposite of the evil man, rather than just a different expression of the same basic impulses that find more direct expression in the evil man. The work moves into the realm "beyond good and evil" in the sense of leaving behind the tradition...

raw.author: Shakespeare
contexts: The case is not different with Shakespeare, that marvelous Spanish-Moorish-Saxon synthesis of taste, over whom an ancient Athenian of the circle of AEschylus would have half-killed himself with laughter or irritation: but we--accept precisely this wild motleyness, this medley of the most delicate, the most coarse, and the most artificial, with a secret confidence and cordiality; we enjoy it as a refinement of art reserved expressly for us
commentaries: The author cites Shakespeare as an example of a complex, hybrid artist whose work is embraced by modern Europeans with historical sense, despite its potentially jarring contrasts for earlier cultures.

raw.author: Heinrich Heine
contexts: not to speak of Heinrich Heine, who has long ago been re-incarnated in the more refined and fastidious lyrists of Paris
commentaries: The author notes that Heinrich Heine's influence has been absorbed and continued by refined lyricists in Paris, indicating his lasting impact on French culture.

raw.author: Helvetius
contexts: just as he had already stalked in the footsteps of the respectable Helvetius!
commentaries: The author references Helvetius as an influence on Bentham and the utilitarian tradition.

raw.author: Descartes
contexts: Unless one should make an exception in the case of Descartes, the father of rationalism (and consequently the grandfather of the Revolution), who recognized only the authority of reason: but reason is only a tool, and Descartes was superficial.
commentaries: The author cites Descartes as the founder of rationalism, critiquing his exclusive reliance on reason as superficial.

raw.author: Horace
contexts: An educator who nowadays preached truthfulness above everything else, and called out constantly to his pupils: "Be true! Be natural! Show yourselves as you are!" --even such a virtuous and sincere ass would learn in a short time to have recourse to the FURCA of Horace, NATURAM EXPELLERE: with what results? "Plebeianism" USQUE RECURRET.
commentaries: The author references Horace's phrase 'Naturam expellere furca, tamen usque recurret' (You may drive out Nature with a pitchfork, yet she will ever return) to illustrate the futility of education trying to suppress inherited plebeian traits.

raw.author: Epicurean
contexts: it operates upon them as the Epicurean philosophy usually operates upon sufferers of a higher order
commentaries: The author references Epicurean philosophy as a comparative example of how religion can refine and justify suffering for the common man.

raw.author: Herbert Spencer
contexts: now that the influence of respectable but mediocre Englishmen--I may mention Darwin, John Stuart Mill, and Herbert Spencer--begins to gain the ascendancy in the middle-class region of European taste.
commentaries: The author includes Herbert Spencer among the mediocre English thinkers whose influence is becoming dominant in European middle-class taste.

raw.author: Bentham
contexts: in the footsteps of Bentham
commentaries: The author mentions Bentham as a predecessor followed by the English utilitarians.

raw.author: Petronius
contexts: so Aristophanes and Petronius are untranslatable for him.
Finally, who would venture on a German translation of Petronius, who, more than any great musician hitherto, was a master of PRESTO in invention, ideas, and words?
commentaries: The author states that Petronius is untranslatable for Germans due to stylistic tempo differences.
The author again cites Petronius, emphasizing his mastery of fast tempo in writing and the difficulty of translating him into German.

raw.author: Kleist
contexts: Those great poets, for example, such as Byron, Musset, Poe, Leopardi, Kleist, Gogol (I do not venture to mention much greater names, but I have them in my mind), as they now appear, and were perhaps obliged to be: men of the moment, enthusiastic, sensuous, and childish, light- minded and impulsive in their trust and distrust...
commentaries: The author cites Heinrich von Kleist as an example of a 'great poet' who is ultimately a tormented and flawed 'man of the moment,' using his work for personal revenge or forgetfulness.

raw.author: Henri Beyle
contexts: and as the most successful expression of genuine French curiosity and inventive talent in this domain of delicate thrills, Henri Beyle may be noted; that remarkable anticipatory and forerunning man, who, with a Napoleonic TEMPO, traversed HIS Europe, in fact, several centuries of the European soul, as a surveyor and discoverer thereof
commentaries: The author praises Henri Beyle (Stendhal) as a profound psychologist and forerunner who explored the European soul, highlighting his unique French psychological curiosity and talent.

raw.author: Galiani
contexts: as in the case of the Abbe Galiani, the profoundest, acutest, and perhaps also filthiest man of his century--he was far profounder than Voltaire, and consequently also, a good deal more silent.
a thoughtful letter of Galiani to Madame d'Epinay
to use an expression of Galiani

There are free insolent minds which would fain conceal and deny that they are broken, proud, incurable hearts (the cynicism of Hamlet--the case of Galiani); and occasionally folly itself is the mask of an unfortunate OVER- ASSURED knowledge.
For as Galiani said, who was obliged to know it: VERTU EST ENTHOUSIASME.
commentaries: The author cites Galiani as an example of a genius bound to an indiscreet nature, describing him as profound and acute.
The author references a letter by Galiani as a documentary source for early symptoms of Europe's moral decline.
The author cites Galiani as the source of a specific expression used to describe Helvetius.
The author references the Abbé Galiani as a historical case, analogous to Hamlet, of a mind using cynicism or folly as a mask to conceal a broken heart and over-assured knowledge.
The author cites Galiani's statement that virtue is enthusiasm, using it to discuss deception and the appearance of stupidity.

raw.author: Carlyle
contexts: the absurd muddle-head, Carlyle, who sought to conceal under passionate grimaces what he knew about himself: namely, what was LACKING in Carlyle--real POWER of intellect, real DEPTH of intellectual perception, in short, philosophy.
commentaries: The author critiques Carlyle as an unphilosophical figure who lacks intellectual depth, using him as an example of what is deficient in the English character.

raw.author: Goethe
contexts: even Goethe's prose, in its mixture of stiffness and elegance, is no exception, as a reflection of the 'good old time' to which it belongs
as has been taught by Hafis and Goethe, the bold letting-go of the reins
and the latter when he interpreted it, 'the eternally feminine draws us ALOFT';

It is a question what Goethe really thought about the Germans?--But about many things around him he never spoke explicitly, and all his life he knew how to keep an astute silence--probably he had good reason for it.
"One can only truly esteem him who does not LOOK OUT FOR himself." --Goethe to Rath Schlosser.
commentaries: The author critiques Goethe's prose as reflecting an older German taste, describing it as stiff and elegant.
The author cites Goethe, alongside Hafis, as exemplifying a moral teaching that involves a complaisant surrender to the passions.
The author references Goethe's interpretation of the 'eternally feminine,' from Faust, as a belief about woman that he claims noble women oppose.
The author references Goethe as a thinker who maintained a deliberate silence on certain matters, implying a complex and strategic relationship to German identity.
The author quotes Goethe's statement to Rath Schlosser as a pithy aphorism on esteem and selflessness, presenting it without further elaboration.

raw.author: St. Augustine
contexts: to use the expression of the holy rhetorician, St. Augustine, who was himself such a man.
commentaries: The author quotes St. Augustine's expression 'Sabbath of Sabbaths' to describe a type of happiness sought by weak men in ages of dissolution.

raw.author: Pascal
contexts: the intellectual conscience of Pascal
as exemplified in the European Christian (Pascal, for instance)
to Pascal-like SACRIFIZIA DELL' INTELLETO
commentaries: The author references Pascal as an example of a soul with profound, bruised, and immense experience, specifically regarding the problem of knowledge and conscience, without mentioning a specific work.
The author cites Pascal as a specific example of the stunted, Christian type of man whose degeneration evokes horror.
The author references Pascal in the context of intellectual self-sacrifice and cruelty towards oneself.

raw.author: Hobbes
contexts: "Laughing is a bad infirmity of human nature, which every thinking mind will strive to overcome" (Hobbes),
commentaries: The author references Hobbes to critique the view that laughter is a weakness, contrasting it with his own valuation of laughter as a sign of philosophical rank.

raw.author: Lessing
contexts: Lessing is an exception, owing to his histrionic nature, which understood much, and was versed in many things; he who was not the translator of Bayle to no purpose, who took refuge willingly in the shadow of Diderot and Voltaire, and still more willingly among the Roman comedy-writers
commentaries: The author describes Lessing as an exception among German writers, noting his versatile nature and influences.

raw.author: Hafis
contexts: as has been taught by Hafis and Goethe, the bold letting-go of the reins
commentaries: The author cites Hafis, alongside Goethe, as teaching a surrender to emotions, presenting it as another form of moral system.

raw.author: Schiller
contexts: how strangely does the language of Rousseau, Schiller, Shelley, and Byron sound to our ear
commentaries: The author groups Schiller with other writers whose language expressed a shared European fate that now seems distant.

raw.author: Gogol

commentaries: The author cites Nikolai Gogol as an example of a 'great poet' who is ultimately a tormented and flawed 'man of the moment,' using his work for personal revenge or forgetfulness.

raw.author: Dante
contexts: I have no doubt that every noble woman will oppose what Dante and Goethe believed about woman—the former when he sang, 'ELLA GUARDAVA SUSO, ED IO IN LEI,'
commentaries: The author references Dante's poetic depiction of woman, specifically a line from the Divine Comedy, to contrast it with what he claims noble women actually believe.

raw.author: Ernest Renan
contexts: And even Ernest Renan: how inaccessible to us Northerners does the language of such a Renan appear, in whom every instant the merest touch of religious thrill throws his refined voluptuous and comfortably couching soul off its balance!
commentaries: The author comments on Ernest Renan's writing, noting its inaccessibility to Northerners due to its refined, voluptuous, and religiously sensitive character.

raw.author: Leibniz
contexts: "JE NE MEPRISE PRESQUE RIEN"-- he says, with Leibniz
